questions.text: What is the name of this suture material?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Plain catgut

questions.text: In a patient with hyperplasia of all four parathyroid glands who undergoes total parathyroidectomy followed by implantation of parathyroid tissue in a different site, which term best defines this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterotopic

 

  • Heterotopic autotransplantation refers to implanting parathyroid tissue at a different site (commonly forearm or sternocleidomastoid) after total parathyroidectomy.
  • Done to preserve some parathyroid function while removing hyperfunctioning glands.
  • This differs from orthotopic (implantation at the original site) and isograft (graft between genetically identical individuals).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isograft: Incorrect. involves grafting tissue between genetically identical individuals, not autotransplantation.

 

Option B. Auxiliary: Incorrect. auxiliary graft usually refers to an additional tissue placed alongside a main organ, not the standard parathyroid transplantation.

 

Option D. Orthotopic: Incorrect. refers to reimplantation at the original anatomical location, not a different site.

choices.text: Increased ACTH and cortisol levels are characteristic findings
Insulin levels are elevated in the ebb phase of stress
There is increased hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipolysis
Growth hormone (GH) and TNF-α levels are elevated

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the metabolic and hormonal response to surgical stress/trauma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insulin levels are elevated in the ebb phase of stress

 

  • The ebb phase occurs immediately after trauma and is characterized by low cardiac output, hypotension, and hypometabolism.
  • Insulin levels are actually decreased, leading to hyperglycemia and insulin resistance in the later flow phase.
  • Cortisol, catecholamines, GH, and TNF-α increase to maintain metabolic homeostasis and mobilize energy substrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased ACTH and cortisol levels are characteristic findings: Correct. these hormones rise to counteract stress and promote gluconeogenesis.

 

Option C. There is Increased hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipolysis: Correct. ensures energy supply for vital organs.

 

Option D. Growth hormone (GH) and TNF-α levels elevated: Correct. GH promotes protein mobilization, TNF-α is part of inflammatory response.

questions.text: For performing a transurethral resection in cases of bladder tumors, which of the following lasers is most commonly used?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Nd-YAG laser

questions.text: All of the following are correctly matched triads with their associated conditions except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Dieulafoy’s Triad – Acute pancreatitis

questions.text: The TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) model incorporates which of the following variables?
questions.solution: Ans. A) RTS + ISS + age

choices.text: Splenectomy is considered after glucocorticoid therapy failure
IVIG is a treatment option in life-threatening bleeding
Romiplostim and eltrombopag are avoided post-splenectomy
Rh(D) immune globulin is used in Rh-positive patients

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the management of Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Romiplostim and eltrombopag are avoided post-splenectomy

 

  • In Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP):
    • Splenectomy is considered for patients who do not respond to glucocorticoid therapy.
    • Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is used in life-threatening bleeding to rapidly increase platelet count.
    • Rh(D) immune globulin is used in Rh-positive patients to treat ITP.
  • Romiplostim and eltrombopag are thrombopoietin receptor agonists used to stimulate platelet production and are not contraindicated after splenectomy; in fact, they can be used in refractory cases regardless of splenectomy status.

questions.text: Which among the following medications must be withheld on the day of surgery due to potential complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Furosemide

 

  • Furosemide is a loop diuretic that can cause intravascular volume depletion, electrolyte imbalance, and hypotension during anesthesia.
  • Withholding it on the day of surgery helps maintain hemodynamic stability and reduces the risk of perioperative complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Continue; important for heart failure and arrhythmia control. Monitor electrolytes.

 

Option C. Propylthiouracil: Continue; prevents thyroid storm perioperatively.

 

Option D. Prednisolone: Continue; stress-dose steroids may be required to prevent adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: All of the following structures are approximately 25 cm in length except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transverse colon

 

The transverse colon is considerably longer than 25 cm, measuring on average 40–45 cm. It extends between the hepatic flexure and the splenic flexure, forming the longest and most mobile part of the colon. Because its length far exceeds 25 cm, it does not belong to the group of structures that are approximately 25 cm in size.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ureter: The ureter runs from the renal pelvis to the urinary bladder, with an average length of 25–30 cm. Its course is divided into abdominal, pelvic, and intramural parts, making it closely match the 25 cm standard.

 

Option B. Duodenum: The duodenum is about 25 cm long and forms a C-shaped loop around the head of the pancreas. It is the shortest yet widest part of the small intestine and is fixed retroperitoneally.

 

Option C. Esophagus: The esophagus extends from the pharynx to the stomach and measures around 25 cm. It passes through the thorax and diaphragm before entering the stomach, making it another structure that fits the 25 cm length group.

questions.text: During a Forensic Medicine Conference, a detailed discussion is held on the mechanisms of death in cases of judicial hanging. One of the topics focuses on the anatomical structures involved in the upper cervical spine and their role in the cause of death when subjected to the forces involved in hanging. A case is presented where an individual subjected to judicial hanging was found to have significant cervical spine injuries during the autopsy. Based on the anatomical and forensic analysis, which of the following structures is most likely to be involved in causing death due to rupture in cases of judicial hanging?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transverse Ligament of Dens 

 

In judicial hanging, the drop is designed to cause a sudden forceful hyperextension and distraction of the cervical spine, particularly around C1–C2 (atlas–axis). The transverse ligament of the dens is crucial for stabilizing the odontoid process (dens) of the axis against the anterior arch of the atlas. Its rupture leads to dislocation of the dens into the spinal cord, causing medullary compression and instant death. This is the most significant forensic finding in judicial hangings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper Band of Cruciate Ligament:

 

  • The upper band connects the dens to the occiput.
  • While it may be strained in cervical trauma, rupture is less commonly the direct cause of fatal instability compared to the transverse ligament.

 

Option B. Apical Ligament of Dens:

 

  • A weak midline structure that connects the dens to the anterior margin of the foramen magnum.
  • Not a major stabilizer of the atlantoaxial joint, so rupture alone is unlikely to cause death.

 

Option D. Membrana Tectoria:

 

  • This is a continuation of the posterior longitudinal ligament extending to the occipital bone.
  • It helps stabilize the craniocervical junction, rupture is not the key forensic mechanism in judicial hanging deaths.

questions.text: All of the following tumor classifications are correctly matched with their associated tumors except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gleason scoring – Testicular cancer

 

  • Gleason scoring is used for prostate cancer, not testicular cancer.
  • Bloom–Richardson grading: histologic grading for breast carcinoma.
  • Duke staging: classic staging for colorectal carcinoma.
  • Masaoka staging: staging system for thymoma, based on invasion and spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bloom–Richardson grading – Carcinoma breast: Correct. evaluates tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic count.

 

Option B. Duke staging – Colorectal carcinoma: Correct. early classification for colorectal cancer prognosis.

 

Option D. Masaoka staging – Thymoma: Correct. assesses capsular invasion and metastasis.

questions.text: A female with ER+, PR+, HER2- breast cancer is to be treated. Which of the following is the most recently approved agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Palbociclib

 

  • Palbociclib is a CDK4/6 inhibitor approved for ER+, PR+, HER2- advanced breast cancer.
  • Works by blocking cell cycle progression from G1 to S phase.
  • Improves progression-free survival when combined with endocrine therapy.
  • Herceptin targets HER2-positive tumors; not indicated in HER2- cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ipatasertib: AKT inhibitor; still under investigation, not standard for ER+ HER2- breast cancer.

 

Option B. Buparlisib: PI3K inhibitor; early-phase studies, not widely approved.

 

Option D. Herceptin:  Trastuzumab; only effective in HER2-positive breast cancer.

choices.text: Annual MRI from 25 years of age in BRCA mutation carriers
Clinical breast exam every 6–12 months after 21 years of age
Women with ≥ 20% lifetime risk require annual imaging

questions.text: All of the following are true about breast cancer screening in high-risk women according to NCCN 2022 guidelines except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Mammogram is contraindicated in pregnancy

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for breast cancer except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Oophorectomy

questions.text:
Breast conservation surgery is feasible in which of the following patients with breast carcinoma?

 

  1. A post-partum woman
  2. Small breast with a large tumor
  3. Persistently positive margin
  4. Diffuse microcalcification on mammogram
  5. Prior chest radiation
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 1

 

  • BCS feasibility depends on:
    • Tumor-to-breast ratio – large tumor in small breast → poor cosmetic outcome.
    • Margins – persistently positive margins contraindicate BCS.
    • Diffuse microcalcifications – usually require mastectomy.
    • Prior chest radiation – increases risk of poor healing and fibrosis.
  • Statement 1. A post-partum woman: With appropriately sized tumor and clear margins can undergo BCS safely.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. Small breast with large tumor: Incorrect. poor cosmetic result, usually requires mastectomy.

 

Statement 3. Persistently positive margin: Incorrect. BCS cannot ensure complete tumor excision.

 

Statement 4. Diffuse microcalcification on mammogram: Incorrect. widespread involvement usually requires mastectomy.

 

Statement 5. Prior chest radiation: Incorrect. increased complication risk post-BCS

questions.text: All of the following signs are correctly matched to their associated condition except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Courvoisier’s sign – Gallbladder perforation

questions.text: A 40-year-old female has a 3 cm mass in the upper quadrant of the right breast. Biopsy confirms invasive ductal carcinoma without nodal spread. What is the ideal management plan?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Breast-conserving surgery with adjuvant radiotherapy

choices.text: Intestinal type is associated with gland formation
Diffuse type has signet ring cells

questions.text: All are true differences between intestinal and diffuse types of gastric carcinoma except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Diffuse type shows hematogenous spread

questions.text: All are positive findings in peritoneal lavage except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) 75 WBCs/μL

choices.text: Amebic more commonly associated with dysentery
Amebic abscess shows high grade fever with chills

questions.text: All are true differences between pyogenic and amebic liver abscesses except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Amebic abscess shows high grade fever with chills

questions.text: All of the following are features of Reynold’s pentad in acute suppurative cholangitis except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Hematemesis

questions.text: A hemicolectomy specimen biopsy shows adenocarcinoma invading the subserosa with deposits in the mesentery but no lymph node involvement or distant spread. What is the tumor stage?
questions.solution: Ans. B) T3 N1c M0

questions.text: In extended left hemi-hepatectomy, the liver segments resected are:
questions.solution: Ans. C) 2, 3, 4, 5, 8

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a history of transient ischemic attacks and several episodes of weakness is referred for diagnostic evaluation. On physical examination, there is a noticeable murmur around the child's temple. Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is performed, revealing the characteristic imaging shown. The following appearance of DSA is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Moya-Moya disease

 

The angiographic image demonstrates a classic “puff of smoke” appearance, which is characteristic of Moya-Moya disease. This disease involves progressive stenosis of the internal carotid arteries and compensatory development of a fine network of collateral vessels, leading to the described smoky vascular pattern on DSA.

 

Moya-Moya typically presents in children with recurrent transient ischemic attacks and focal neurological deficits. The presence of a bruit (vascular murmur) over the temple further supports the diagnosis due to increased collateral flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ICA aneurysm: Would show a localized outpouching or ballooning of the vessel on angiography, not a diffuse network of vessels.

 

 

Option C. Cerebral infarction: Usually results in hypoperfusion zones or absence of flow.

 

Option D. Carotid artery thrombosis: Would show abrupt cutoff or absence of flow in the involved vessel, without the collateral vascularization seen here.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman undergoes hemithyroidectomy for treatment of localized, well- differentiated papillary thyroid carcinoma. The lesion is removed with clear margins. However, during the surgery, a structure lying directly adjacent to the superior thyroid artery at the upper pole of the thyroid lobe is damaged. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Voice pitch limitation

questions.text: Histopathological examination of a polyp shows dysplasia up to the submucosa. What is the correct Haggitt classification level?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Level 4

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with hematuria and left flank pain. Imaging studies reveal a renal mass, and a subsequent biopsy confirms the diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is most characteristic of papillary chromophilic renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trisomy 7/17

 

  • Papillary RCC (chromophilic type) is most commonly associated with trisomy of chromosomes 7 and 17 and loss of Y in males.
  • This contrasts with clear cell RCC, which is commonly linked to loss of 3p and VHL gene mutations.
  • Xp translocations are characteristic of MiT family translocation RCC, seen mainly in children and young adults.
  • Cytogenetic profiling helps in diagnosis, prognosis, and targeted therapy planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loss of 3p: Incorrect. typical of clear cell RCC, seen in VHL syndrome.

 

Option C. Xp translocation: Incorrect. seen in translocation-associated RCC, mostly in pediatric patients.

 

Option D. Mutant VHL gene: Incorrect. hallmark of clear cell RCC, leading to HIF pathway activation.

choices.text: Tender point medial to the anterior inferior iliac spine
Pelvic side shift to the left

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of low back pain and spasms radiating down his leg. He works as a delivery driver and reports that the pain worsens as the day progresses. He takes acetaminophen, which provides temporary relief. He denies any recent trauma. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin. Physical examination reveals:

 

  • Restricted hip extension on the left
  • Lumbar hyperlordosis
  • Hypertonic right piriformis

 

Further evaluation is most likely to show:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Positive Thomas test

questions.text: Which type of renal stone is commonly associated with chronic laxative abuse?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Ammonium urate

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit due to severe sepsis caused by a ruptured abdominal abscess. She has been receiving high-dose intravenous corticosteroids for hypotension management over the past three days. On examination, she is alert but appears critically ill. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

  • TSH: 1.2 µU/mL (normal range: 0.4–4.0 µU/mL)
  • Free T4: 1.1 ng/dL (normal range: 0.8–1.8 ng/dL)
  • Free T3: 0.6 pg/mL (normal range: 2.0–4.4 pg/mL)

 

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Euthyroid sick syndrome

choices.text: It can cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB)
Paramagnetic material which can shorten the T1 relaxation time
Long-term studies show gadolinium deposition in the basal ganglia at high doses

questions.text: During a radiology department seminar, a discussion focuses on the properties and safety of gadolinium-based contrast agents. Which of the following statements about gadolinium is false?
questions.solution: Ans. A) It can cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB)

questions.text: Abbe-Estlander flap is primarily used in the reconstruction of which region?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Lip

questions.text: In a case of head injury, which patient would not require an immediate CT scan?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) One episode of vomiting

 

A single, isolated vomiting episode after head injury in an otherwise neurologically stable patient is considered low-risk and does not mandate immediate CT. CT is reserved for multiple episodes of vomiting or when associated with other red-flag features such as altered mental status, seizures, or focal deficits. Clinical observation is sufficient in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Child with post-traumatic seizure: Any seizure following head trauma increases the risk of intracranial bleeding or cortical contusion. CT scan is mandatory to rule out parenchymal or extra-axial hematoma.

 

Option B. Biker with skull fracture suspicion: Suspected skull fractures, especially basilar or depressed, always warrant urgent CT to detect underlying hematoma or dural tears. Clinical suspicion alone is enough to justify scanning.

 

Option C. RTA victim with GCS 12: A GCS less than 13 is a red flag for moderate to severe traumatic brain injury. These patients are at high risk of intracranial hematoma or cerebral edema and require immediate CT.

 

Canadian CT Head Rule

 

Patients would require a CT scan if any of the high-risk (to identify lesions re-quiring neurosurgical intervention) or medium-risk (to identify any significant CT abnormality) criteria are present:

 

High-Risk Criteria

 

  • Failure of GCS to reach 15 within 2 hours of injury
  • Suspected open or depressed skull fracture
  • Any sign of basal skull fracture
  • Two or more episodes of vomiting
  • Age 65 years or over

 

Medium-Risk Criteria

 

  • Amnesia extending back more than 30 minutes before injury
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., pedestrian struck by vehicle, fall from more than 3 feet or down more than 5 stairs, ejection from vehicle during a collision

 

(Patients could have LOC, some amnesia, and disorientation, as well as a GCS as low as 13 initially; those under age 16 and with focal neurological deficits or anticoagulation/coagulopathy were not included.)

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency with abdominal pain and an episode of binge drinking, in shock with a BP of 70/50 mmHg and HR of 115/min. The oxygen saturation of the patient is 70 mmHg. The serum creatinine level was 2.4 mg/dL. What is the likely diagnosis based on the CT image shown below?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Necrotising Acute pancreatitis

choices.text: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, deep fascia
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, deep fascia, muscle fibers

questions.text: Fasciotomy for compartment syndrome involves cutting through which of the following layers?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, deep fascia

questions.text: What is the procedure being shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Billroth II reconstruction

 

The image shows a surgical procedure in which the distal stomach is resected and the gastric remnant is anastomosed to the side of the jejunum, bypassing the duodenum, which is characteristic of Billroth II (gastrojejunostomy) reconstruction.

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Billroth I reconstruction: Involves gastroduodenostomy, connecting the stomach to the duodenum.


Option C. Braun anastomosis: An additional side-to-side jejunojejunostomy, not visualized here.

 

 

Option D. Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy: Features a Y-shaped configuration, with separation of the alimentary and biliopancreatic limbs, different from the simple gastrojejunostomy shown.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Triple H therapy used in the management of vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

Triple H therapy is a classic supportive treatment for cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

It consists of:

 

  1. Hypertension → increases cerebral perfusion pressure.
  2. Hypervolemia → expands intravascular volume, maintaining cerebral blood flow.
  3. Hemodilution → lowers blood viscosity, improving flow through narrowed vessels.

 

Hypothermia is not part of Triple H; it has experimental neuroprotective roles but is not included in vasospasm management protocol.

questions.text: A 30-year-old multiparous woman presents with chronic lower back pain. The pain is non-radiating, worse with activity, and improves with rest. There are no neurological deficits. X-ray pelvis shows bilateral symmetric sclerosis of the iliac side of the sacroiliac joints, with joint spaces preserved. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteitis condensans ilii

 

The most likely diagnosis for a multiparous woman with chronic non-radiating lower back pain, preserved sacroiliac joint spaces, and bilateral symmetric iliac-side sclerosis on pelvic X-ray is osteitis condensans ilii.

 

  • Osteitis condensans ilii presents with characteristic bilateral, symmetric triangular sclerosis of the iliac side of the sacroiliac joints, seen 
  • especially in multiparous women.

 

The joint spaces remain preserved and there are no associated neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and C. Ankylosing spondylitis and sacroiliitis: typically show erosions, joint space narrowing, or eventually ankylosis.

 

Option D. Metastatic bone disease: Metastatic bone disease would present with lytic or blastic lesions, not symmetric sclerosis limited to the iliac side of SI joints.

choices.text: String sign indicates a persistent narrow stream of barium due to stenosis
Fleischner sign or inverted umbrella sign is due to narrowing of the terminal ileum
Gooseneck deformity is caused by dilated terminal ileum with loss of ileocecal angle
Pulled-up cecum occurs due to hypertrophy of the mesocolon

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding barium studies in gastrointestinal tuberculosis, except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Pulled-up cecum occurs due to hypertrophy of the mesocolon

choices.text: Presence of foreign body in the tract

questions.text: All are true regarding factors preventing spontaneous closure of a fistula, except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Presence of fibrosis

choices.text: Radiography uses tungsten as the target, while mammography uses molybdenum
Beryllium is used as the exit window in mammography
Mammography uses Bremsstrahlung radiation for better tissue contrast
Aluminum filter is used in radiography, while molybdenum is used in mammography

questions.text: All of the following are correct differences between normal radiography and mammography, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Mammography uses Bremsstrahlung radiation for better tissue contrast

choices.text: Traction → External rotation → Adduction → Medial rotation
Traction → External rotation → Abduction → Medial rotation

questions.text: While performing Kocher’s method for reducing anterior shoulder dislocation, which is the correct sequence of movements?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Traction → External rotation → Adduction → Medial rotation

questions.text: Psammoma bodies are seen in all of the following, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Clear cell RCC

questions.text: All are valid indications for surgery in asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age >60 years

 

  • Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism if there is end-organ involvement or high-risk biochemical abnormalities.
  • Vertebral fractures indicate skeletal involvement → surgical indication.
  • Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above ULN increases risk of complications → surgical indication.
  • High 24-hour urine calcium (>400 mg/day) may indicate risk of nephrolithiasis → surgical indication.
  • Age >60 years alone is not a standalone indication; management can be conservative in elderly asymptomatic patients.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vertebral fracture: Correct indication. reflects skeletal involvement from hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above ULN: Correct indication. risk of nephrolithiasis and other complications.

 

Option D. 24-hour urine calcium >400 mg/day: Correct indication. increased risk of kidney stones or nephrocalcinosis.

choices.text: Sudden cardiac arrest survivors with ischemia-mediated VT

questions.text: All of the following are Class I indications for CABG, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Two-vessel disease without LAD involvement

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for the following fracture?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Internal fixation using compression plate

questions.text: A 4-year-old presents with a pink but pulseless arm following an injury. Xray is shown below. What is the best next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduction and pinning

 

The X-ray shows a supracondylar fracture of the humerus, common in children. The clinical finding of a pink but pulseless hand indicates brachial artery injury due to kinking, compression, or spasm—not complete transection. In this scenario, the best initial step is urgent closed reduction and percutaneous pinning to restore normal anatomy, which usually relieves vascular compromise. Immediate vascular repair is not needed unless the limb remains ischemic after reduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation: Not appropriate; vascular compromise requires urgent intervention.

 

Option B. Vascular repair: Reserved only if pulses do not return after reduction and stabilization.

 

Option C. Fasciotomy: Done if there are signs of compartment syndrome, not the first-line step here.

questions.text: All of the following radioisotopes have a half-life of less than 1 day, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Iodine 125

questions.text: All of the following are considered radioprotectors, except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Cisplatin

choices.text: Alpha particles have high ionisation ability
Alpha particles have highest molecular mass among radiations

questions.solution: Ans. C) Alpha particles are the most penetrating form of radiation

questions.solution: Ans. C)  Burkhalter cast – Developmental dysplasia of hip

questions.solution: Ans. B) Open reduction

questions.solution: Ans. C) Javelin thrower’s elbow – Olecranon bursitis

questions.solution: Ans. C) Mayo classification – Shoulder instability

Spica cast is preferred for ages 6 months to 5 years
Flexible nails are used in adolescents >10 years

questions.text: All are true about treatment of femoral shaft fracture in different pediatric age groups, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Flexible nails are used in adolescents >10 years

Middle column includes posterior part of disc and posterior longitudinal ligament
Posterior column contains spinous process and PLL
Involvement of middle column with another column is considered unstable

questions.text: All of the following are part of the Denis column theory for vertebral fractures, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Posterior column contains spinous process and PLL

choices.text: Neuropraxia involves segmental demyelination without axonal damage
Axonotmesis involves axonal interruption with intact neural tubes
Neurotmesis results from temporary ischemia with full recovery

questions.text: All are true about types of nerve injuries, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Neurotmesis results from temporary ischemia with full recovery

questions.text: A 11-month-old boy with CTEV has not responded to POP casting over 6 months. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Turco’s procedure

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of swelling and unusual heaviness of his scrotum that he first noticed a few weeks ago. The symptoms improve when he is lying in bed. He also reports a 5-kg weight loss and increasing fatigue over the past 6 months. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of his right flank. There are soft strands palpable in the right hemiscrotum superior of the right testis. The strands increase with Valsalva maneuver. Applying a bright light to the right hemiscrotum shows no transillumination. Obstruction of venous drainage into which of the following vessels is most likely responsible for this patient's scrotal enlargement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inferior vena cava

 

  • The patient has a right-sided varicocele (soft strands above testis, increases with Valsalva, non-transilluminating).
  • Sudden-onset or adult varicocele on the right side in a patient >40 years suggests secondary varicocele due to obstruction of venous drainage, commonly from retroperitoneal mass compressing the IVC (renal cell carcinoma, retroperitoneal tumor).
  • Right testicular vein drains directly into the IVC, whereas the left drains into the left renal vein. Hence IVC obstruction affects the right side predominantly.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Right internal iliac vein: Drains the pelvis; unlikely to cause isolated right-sided varicocele.

 

Option B. Right inferior rectal vein: Drains anorectal region; obstruction would cause hemorrhoids, not varicocele.

 

Option C. Right renal vein: Left-sided varicoceles are more commonly associated with left renal vein compression (Nutcracker syndrome), not right-sided.

questions.text: All of the following are correct about ACS guidelines for average-risk population for colorectal carcinoma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Colonoscopy every 5 years

 

  • Reasoning:
  • According to ACS (American Cancer Society) guidelines for average-risk adults:
    • Start screening at 45–50 years
    • FOBT or FIT: annually
    • Flexible sigmoidoscopy: every 5 years
    • Colonoscopy: every 10 years, not 5 years
  • Colonoscopy allows visualization of the entire colon and polyp removal, so it is the preferred modality, but 10-year interval is recommended if normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Begin screening at 50 years: Correct. some guidelines now suggest 45 years.

 

Option B. Annual FOBT: Correct. non-invasive test for occult bleeding.

 

Option C. Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years: Correct. visualizes distal colon, can be combined with FOBT.

questions.text: All of the following are minimum standards for monitoring of a patient in shock except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Base deficit

 

Base deficit is an advanced laboratory marker of metabolic acidosis and tissue hypoperfusion, but it is not considered a minimum standard parameter for routine monitoring at the bedside for patients in shock.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. ECG: Essential for cardiac monitoring and rhythm assessment in shock.
 

Option B. Pulse oximetry: Mandatory for continuous monitoring of oxygen saturation in critically ill patients.
 

Option C. Urine output: Key indicator of end-organ perfusion and response to treatment, monitored via catheter.

 

ECG, pulse oximetry, and urine output are universally standard for shock monitoring; base deficit is not

choices.text: Infant is at least 10 weeks old
Hemoglobin level of 10 grams per deciliter

questions.text: Millard's Rule of 10 for indications of cleft lip surgery include all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Defect is 10 mm

 

  • Millard’s Rule of 10 is a safety guideline for timing cleft lip repair:
  1. Age ≥ 10 weeks
  2. Weight ≥ 10 pounds (~4.5 kg)
  3. Hemoglobin ≥ 10 g/dL
  • There is no criterion regarding the size of the cleft (10 mm).
  • The rule ensures the infant is physiologically stable to tolerate anesthesia and surgery safely.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Infant is at least 10 weeks old: Correct, ensures adequate maturity and reduced anesthesia risk.

 

Option B. Infant weighs around 10 pounds: Correct, adequate weight reduces perioperative complications.

 

Option C. Hemoglobin level of 10 grams per deciliter: Correct, ensures sufficient oxygen-carrying capacity during surgery.

questions.text: Identify what is depicted in the abdominal X-Ray.
questions.solution: Ans. B) Retrograde pyelogram

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman experiences an increased frequency of micturition, with pain relieved by micturition and aggravated by overdistension of the bladder. Urine routine tests showed no pus cells and cystoscopy revealed fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa as shown in the image below. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Interstitial cystitis

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the skeletal survey of a 10-year-old boy with recurrent fractures?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Osteopetrosis
